prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Detection of SNXX-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Initial continuum detection of SNXX-1 in band 3, to be carried out ~ 15 days after triggering ToO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- SENSITIVITY: Our sensitivity is motivated by those typically achieved with the VLA and ATCA ToO programs at 8.5 GHz of 0.1 mJy rms. At early times, we expect the SNe will be absorbed at 8.5 GHz but unabsorbed at 90 GHz, such that 90 GHz will be equal to or brighter. Thus we strive for an rms of 50 uJy for a 5*sigma sensitivity of 0.25 mJy (or a luminosity at 8.5GHz of L~1E+27 erg/s/Hz at D=25 Mpc), which can be achieved in 0.5 hr.
- IMAGING REQUIREMENTS: The SNe will be a point source for ALMA, and thus we can use the highest resolution ALMA offers without missing flux. However, due to their transient nature, we can observe them in any configuration so as to achieve our science priorities, as long as the SN can still be disentangled from its host galaxy.
- CORRELATOR SETUP: We request the use of four basebands with the largest bandwidth offered for continuum mode (7.5GHz effectively). We have chosen the local oscillator frequency near the low frequency end of band 3 to achieve the best S/N given the declining nature of the synchrotron spectrum (nu^(-0.7), S_nu ~ nu^(alpha)).
- CALIBRATION no special requirements
- BANDPASS ACCURACY We consider a small overlap of the basebands to account for the roll-off at their edges, thus avoiding the consequent loss of sensitivity.
- SCHEDULING/TIME CONSTRAINTS We will work with the ALMA schedulers to facilitate observations of potential radio SNe in the most timely manner possible and we will only trigger our ToO when useful observations can be scheduled, to the benefit of both our program and the ALMA observatory. As mentioned above, we will execute an initial trigger to secure our expected detection and then run through a cadence spanning ~3 months. Given the diversity of radio SNe (e.g., fast evolving, long-lasting, etc.), we request some flexibility in how the follow-up time is used.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: First follow-up of SNXX-a

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a pilot study to observe five core-collapse supernovae (CCSNe) as Targets of Opportunity with ALMA in Band 3 to aid the understanding of CCSNe through the study of the mass-loss rate, absorption mechanisms, and density distribution of the pre-SN circumstellar envelopes established by strong stellar winds. Robust early mm-continuum constraints can provide intrinsic spectral and temporal baselines to help break typical degeneracies and ambiguities in the multifrequency radio light curves as young CCSNe transition from optically-thick to optically-thin regimes. Accurate assessment of the decreasing self-absorption is an important probe of the physical conditions of the circumstellar medium (B- field and free-electron distribution) which can be used to improve our understanding of the various CCSN subtypes (drawn based on their optical spectra and light-curve shape) whilst providing an insight on their progenitors. High- quality observations like we propose here ultimately seed decade-long monitoring campaigns to study the last several 1000's yr of stellar evolution before explosion and provide targets for resolved VLBI studies of the SN-shock development and evolution.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This is a re-submission of the proposal submitted in Cycle 1 with the following details: Code: 2012.1.01118.T Title: SNe TOO to Constrain the CSM around Young SNe with ALMA PI name: F. E. Bauer

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astrophysics, Pontifical Catholic University of Chile
